metadata./Title: Carbimazole-induced eosinophilic gastroenteritis in a young female with abdominal pain and ascites: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Eosinophilic gastroenteritis is a rare disease characterized by eosinophilic infiltration into one or more 
layers of the gastrointestinal tract. It commonly affects children more than adults. The clinical features depend 
on the site of gut involvement, but the most common symptoms include abdominal pain and diarrhea. The most 
common cause reported in the literature is hypersensitivity, as many patients have a history of seasonal allergies, 
atopy, asthma, food allergies, and so on. However, drugs can be a rare triggering factor. In the literature review, we 
found multiple case reports of eosinophilic gastroenteritis; however, only one other case of carbimazole-induced 
eosinophilic gastritis has been reported.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We report herein the case of a 36-year-old female from the Philippines who developed 
eosinophilic gastroenteritis localized to the esophagus and ileum 12 months following treatment with carbimazole for hyperthyroidism. In our facility, she was extensively investigated for malignancy, autoimmune pathologies 
and infectious etiologies. As the symptoms coincided with carbimazole exposure and other causes were ruled out, 
we labeled her as carbimazole-induced eosinophilic gastroenteritis. On subsequent follow-up after discharge, her 
symptoms and eosinophilia resolved when carbimazole was discontinued, suggesting a causative role. This is the first 
case of eosinophilic gastroenteritis secondary to carbimazole encountered in our region.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Diagnosis of eosinophilic gastroenteritis requires three criteria, namely (1) presence of gastrointestinal 
symptoms, (2) histologic evidence of eosinophilic infiltration in one or more areas of the gastrointestinal tract, and (3) 
exclusion of other causes of tissue eosinophilia. Our patient fulfilled all the criteria; additionally, she had a positive history of atopic tendencies and drug exposure. The diagnosis of hyperthyroidism was established a year ago 
and in another facility, so we were not sure of the underlying etiology of hyperthyroidism. Upon subsequent followup, her thyroid function remained stable. The case highlights the need for a collaborative multidisciplinary approach 
toward managing rare conditions.
Keywords  Eosinophilia, Gastroenteritis, Ascites, Drug-induced

Case presentation
The patient is a 36-year-old single female resident in the 
United Arab Emirates (UAE) but originates from the 
Philippines. She presented to our emergency department 
with a 2-week history of epigastric pain radiating to both 
upper quadrants and aggravated by food and strenuous 
activity. Associated symptoms included reduced appetite, 
abdominal distention, night sweats, fatigue, and two epi sodes of non-bloody vomiting. There was no change in 
bowel habits, fever, weight loss, or jaundice.
Her medical history was significant for a diagnosis of 
hyperthyroidism established a year prior, for which she 
was prescribed carbimazole 5  mg daily. She decided to 
discontinue taking carbimazole two weeks after the start 
of her symptoms. She was prescribed pantoprazole and 
antibiotics before presenting to our institution; however, 
it did not improve her symptoms. There was no history of 
smoking or alcohol consumption. She has regular men strual cycles.
On examination, she was afebrile and hemodynami cally stable. She looked well in general appearance. The 
examination was significant for epigastric tenderness 
and generalized abdominal distention with positive shift ing dullness. There was no pedal edema or raised jugular 
venous pressure (JVP). The chest was clear on ausculta tion. No rash or joint involvement was noticed. Thyroid 
and associated examinations were unremarkable.
Investigations
Initial laboratory tests shown in Tables  1 and 2 revealed 
an elevated white cell count with significant eosino philia. Inflammatory markers were normal, including 
erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), liver function 
tests, thyroid function tests, and stool routine analysis. 
Contrast computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen 
and pelvis shown in Fig.  1 revealed diffuse circumferen tial wall thickening involving the antrum, pyloric region, 
duodenum, and proximal ileal loops (likely of infective/
inflammatory aetiology) and moderate to severe ascites 
(Fig.  1). Ultrasound-guided aspiration of the ascitic fluid, 
detailed in Table  3, revealed an eosinophil-rich exuda tive fluid with a total cell count of 1749 cells/mm3 with 
reactive mesothelial cells. Two liters of fluid were drained 
in total. The cytology report was negative for malignant 
cells. Tuberculosis (TB) polymerase chain reaction (PCR) 
of the ascitic fluid was also negative.Other tests performed included tumor markers and 
serological tests for parasitic infections, including 
Ascaris , Strongyloides, Echinococcus, and Schistosoma 
antibodies, all of which were normal. The autoimmune 
workup shown in Table  4 was unremarkable, including 
antinuclear antibodies (ANA), antineutrophil cytoplas mic antibodies (ANCA), extractable nuclear antigen anti bodies (ENA), anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA), 
celiac, and thyroid antibodies (Table 4).
She was referred to a gastroenterologist for an upper 
gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy, depicted in Fig.  2,

early appointment to the gastroenterology clinic. How ever, she was readmitted after 1 week with similar com plaints. Her biopsy was reported by this time as follows:
• Esophageal biopsy: superficial fragments of squa mous mucosa showing high set congested papillae, 
few scattered eosinophils 8–10/HPF (high power 
field) and mild cell hyperplasia.• Gastric biopsy: mild chronic gastritis with no evi dence of Helicobacter pylori, intestinal metaplasia, 
dysplasia, or malignancy.
• Duodenal biopsy: focal denuded villi and partly intact 
villi. No other abnormality was detected.
A colonoscopy was done in the second admission, 
which was normal, but biopsies were taken from the ter minal ileum. The biopsy later reported mild nonspecific 
inflammatory changes with a predominance of eosino phils in the lamina propria (up to 50 eosinophils/HPF) 
without intraepithelial eosinophils.
Differential diagnosis
Based on her initial lab workup, eosinophilic gastroen teritis was the most likely diagnosis for this lady, which 
was later confirmed on biopsy from the duodenum and 
terminal ileum shown in Fig.  3. Since she had a history of 
carbimazole intake, we entertained that as the most likely 
cause, as all other possible causes of hypereosinophilia, 
such as parasitic infections, vasculitis, autoimmune dis orders, tuberculosis, and malignancy, were ruled out.
Treatment
The patient responded well to oral prednisolone 40 mg/
day and was discharged with follow-up in the gastroen terology and endocrinology clinics.
Outcome and follow‑up
On her follow-up visit after 2 weeks, she was clinically 
better, with no abdominal pain, and improved appetite.

sections.Discussion:
Discussion
The most striking abnormality in this case was the 
marked eosinophilia, evident from the full blood count 
(FBC), blood film, ascitic fluid, and gastrointestinal 
biopsies (Fig.  3). The challenge was deciphering the trig ger and reassuring the patient of a favorable diagnosis. 
Eosinophilic gastroenteritis (EGE) is a rare inflammatory 
disorder characterized by eosinophilic infiltration of the intestinal wall [1]. First described eight decades ago, it 
remains a mystery due to the wide variations in clinical 
presentations [5]. Not much is known about the preva lence of this condition in our region, but studies from the 
USA have found a prevalence of 8.4 to 28 per 100,000, 
with a stable increase in incidence over the past 50 years 
[6]. In adults, it typically affects those in their third and 
fourth decades of life [1]. Risk factors for developing the 
disease are multifactorial. Reports of familial cases sug gest genetic factors may also play a role [7].
The presence of allergic disorders, including asthma, rhi nitis, eczema, and drug or food intolerances, are present 
in 45% to 63% of the reported EGE cases [8 , 9]; moreover, 
64% of reported cases include a family history of atopic 
diseases [10, 11]. Some studies have found an association 
with other autoimmune conditions, such as celiac disease 
[7], ulcerative colitis [9 ] and systemic lupus erythematosus 
[10]. These data collectively suggest that EGE may result 
from immune dysregulation in response to an allergic 
reaction, yet a triggering allergen is not always identified. 
Other environmental factors, such as parasitic infestation 
and drugs, may also act as predisposing agents [8 , 9].
Conclusions
Diagnosis of EGE requires three criteria, namely (1) pres ence of gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms, (2) histologic evi dence of eosinophilic infiltration in one or more areas of 
the GI tract, and (3) exclusion of other causes of tissue 
eosinophilia. Our patient fulfilled all the criteria; addi tionally, she had a positive history of atopic tendencies 
and drug exposure. The diagnosis of hyperthyroidism
